description.en: Once you got familiar with how speed is generated by the different sizes of gears, let's study the physics behind slowing down.
For this challenge you will need the same model what we used during the previous challenge.
We already know that the same size of gears don't change the speed of one and other.
We have also learnt that the bigger the driver gear is, the faster the driven gear will rotate.
Now let's see what happens if we swap the gears. First, let's use a 40-tooth-gear as a driven gear and a 20-tooth-gear as a driver gear.

If the driver gear is is half times smaller than the driven gear, it will halve its speed, so the wheel will run 50% slower. In other words, with one spin of the handle, our wheel will rotate a half circle.br/20/40=0.5br/0.5x40=20
Now let's use a 60-tooth-gear as a driven gear with a 20-tooth-gear driver gear to move the wheel even slower. How many rounds does the wheel turn with one spin of the handle?

If the driver gear has three times fewer gears than the driven gear, it will slow its speed down by three times. Our wheel will rotate a 0.33 circle with one spin of a handle.br/20/60=0.33br/0.33x60=20
How many rounds does the wheel rotate if we attach a 40-tooth-gear (driver gear) to a 60-tooth-gear (driven gear)?
The wheel rotates 0.66 rounds with one spin of the handle.br/40/60=0.66br/0.66x60=40
